column1: Portici (Italian pronunciation: [ˈpɔrtitʃi]) is a town and comune of the Metropolitan City of Naples in Italy. It is the site of the Portici Royal Palace.
Portici lies at the foot of Mount Vesuvius on the Bay of Naples
column2: about 8 km (5.0 mi) southeast of Naples itself. There is a small port. To the south east is Ercolano
column4: which occupies the site of ancient Herculaneum. San Giorgio a Cremano is another town nearby.

column1: The city was completely destroyed by the Eruption of Vesuvius in 1631
column2: but was rebuilt. Charles III of Spain
column4: built a royal palace in the town between 1738–1748. After Garibaldi defeated the Bourbons in 1860
column5: the palace was turned into the Portici botanic gardens and the Royal Higher School of Agriculture.  It once contained the antiquities from Herculaneum
column6: which have since been moved to Naples.

column1: The inhabitants were historically engaged in fishing
column2: silk-growing and silk-weaving up to the beginning of the 20th century. Later a more diversified economy emerged
column3: with industry and trade as main pillars.Vincenzo Cuomo is the mayor.  In 2009
column4: he banned shops from displaying Christmas decorations because shopkeepers were subject to extortion to buy Camorra (mob) sold decorations.In March 2008
column5: Boeing opened a research centre for advanced materials under an agreement with the Italian aerospace company Alenia.
